School of energy and environment Southeast University Nanjing 210096 China The production of furanic biofuel 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF) has been studied by hydrodeoxygenation of biomass-derived levulinic acid (LA) over bimetallic NiCo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The contents of Ni and Co in NiCo/γ-Al2O3 were investigated. The Ni5Co25/γ-Al2O3 catalyst gave high activity in hydrodeoxygenation of LA with a 73.4% yield of 2-MTHF under optimal conditions. The crystal phase, valence states, acidity and basicity of catalysts were measured by multiple characterizations to understand the relationships among 2-MTHF yields and catalyst properties. XPS characterization revealed that the number of metal oxides increased on bimetallic catalysts while the reduced metals occupied on monometallic catalysts. The bimetallic catalysts also presented increased acidity than that of monometallic catalysts. These distinct properties were also observed among bimetallic catalysts with different contents of Ni and Co, which were responsible for different performances. Besides, the solvent effect on the structure of 1,4-pentanediol, which was further converted to 2-methyltetrahydrofuran, was disclosed by molecular dynamics simulations. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Insights into Ni/Co ratio of bimetallic NiCo catalyst and solvent effect on efficient hydrogenolysis of levulinic acid to furanic biofuel 2-methyltetrahydrofuran Keywords Biomass Furanic biofuel Levulinic acid 2-methyltetrahydrofuran Molecular Dynamics simulation 1 Introduction The challenge from carbon neutrality policy provided a window of opportunity to progress the development of sustainable fuels and chemicals. As one of the sustainable carbon resources, biomass has been widely studied to be transformed into biofuels and chemicals [1–3]. The lignocellulosic biomass derived carbohydrates, for example, can be converted to biofuel [1–3], gasoline [4,5], jet-fuel, [6] furfuryl alcohol, [7] and other value-added products [8–10]. Among the biofuels, 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF) is one of more promising biofuel and gasoline additive than ethanol owing to its lower miscibility with water, higher heating value and energy density, and more excellent stability, despite its lower octane number (87 vs. 108.6) [10–12]. In commercial production, 2-MTHF is generally produced from furfural by using the corncob (hemicellulose) as the raw material (Scheme 1 ) [13]. Recently, a novel route of 2-MHTF derived from cellulose has been reported by hydrodeoxygenation of levulinic acid (LA) and γ-valerolactone (GVL) [11–18], which can be readily produced from hydrolysis of cellulose and carbohydrates in acidic solution (Scheme 1). [22] The heterogeneous catalysts applied in this route include noble and non-noble metals. The noble catalyst Pd-Re/C showed the activity with a 2-MTHF yield of 40%, while the yields of 2-MTHF were 54.9% and 82% over the catalyst Ru/C12 and Pt-Mo/H-β, [19] respectively. The non-noble catalysts were mainly Cu-based catalyst owing to the high activity of Cu in hydrogenation of GVL especially the ring-opening reaction. [14] Besides the non-noble monometallic Cu-based catalysts Cu/SiO2 [20,4], Cu/SiO2-Al2O3, [21] Cu-MINT (Microwave Induced Nanotubes) [22,6], and Cu/ZrO2 OG (oxalate-gel-coprecipitation), [23] Co/SiO2 [24] was also developed for LA hydrodeoxygenation. Later, the bimetallic NiCu catalysts with different Ni/Cu ratios were reported in many studies due to enhanced catalytic performance [25–27]. The 23Ni-12Cu/Al2O3 was developed by Arias et al. and a 2-MTHF yield of 56% was obtained under conditions of 250 °C, 70 bar H2, and 5 h in 2-propanol medium. [25] The 4Ni-35Cu/SiO2 showed a different performance that the yield of 2-MTHF from ethyl-levulinate hydrodeoxygenation was 67%, [26] while the Cu-Ni/Al2O3-ZrO2 showed exceptional performance with 99.8% yield of 2-MTHF obtained. [27] Very recently, Huang et al. employed the 10Cu-5Ni/Al2O3 for LA hydrodeoxygenation and obtained 98% 2-MTHF yield. [14] The varied catalytic performance highlighted the importance of M1/M2 ratio in bimetallic catalyst M1M2 which can tune the activity. The scheme 1 showed the reported reaction route to obtain 2-MTHF from hydrodeoxygenation of LA [11–18]. LA was firstly converted to 1,4-pentanediol (1,4-PeD) through the intermediate GVL. While dehydration of 1,4-PeD leads to the formation of the target 2-MTHF, the CC cleavage reaction results in the formation of monoalcohol 2-butanol and CO cleavage leads to 2-pentanol. It suggested that the dehydration and CC cleavage reaction were the competition reactions in this route. Therefore, it is of importance to alter the hydrogenation center and the acidic sites to tune the activity and improve the 2-MTHF selectivity. In this study, we employed the NiCo catalyst with different ratios of Ni/Co to gain more inherent insights into the relationship between catalyst and LA hydrodeoxygenation. We also note that solvent is another important factor in the 1,4-PeD-to-2-MTHF step. Previous reports already highlighted the significant role of solvent in the transformation of LA to 2-MTHF [14,17,19,27]. Water and organic solvent such as poor hydrogen donor 1, 4-dioxane and 1-butanol, hydrogen donor 2-propanol, and nonpolar n-hexane were examined [14,17,19,27]. Water has been suggested as a negative factor which caused reverse reaction of dehydration. [28] While the reactivity was improved in poor hydrogen donor solvents, the best performance was observed in the 2-propanol and n-hexane solvents. Previous studies highlighted the essential role of 2-propanol in assisting the reaction which provided hydride, [17] while the n-hexane solvent facilitated the H2 diffusion to the active metal surface. [14] Besides these factors, we hypothesized that the solvent could affect the structure of the intermediate 1,4-PeD, which is one of the important purposes in this study. In this work, we performed LA hydrodeoxygenation to 2-MTHF over mono- and bimetallic NiCo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Multiple techniques were employed to understand the relationship between the surface properties such as metal and acidic sites and the reactivity. We also performed experiments and molecular dynamics simulations to figure out the essential role of solvent in LA hydrodeoxygenation to 2-MTHF. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and catalyst preparation Co(NO3)3·6H2O (99%), Ni(NO3)3·6H2O (98%), γ-valerolactone (GVL, 98.0%), 2-Methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF, 99%), 2-butanol (99%), 2-pentanol (99.5%), and 1,4-pentanediol (1,4-PeD, 98%) were purchased from Macklin Co., Ltd.. Nano γ-Al2O3 and Levulinic acid (LA, 99.0%) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation. Ethanol (EtOH,99.9%) and 2-propanol were purchased from Tianjin Fuyu Chemical Corporation. We employed the impregnation approach to prepare catalysts. Typically, the support γ-Al2O3 was suspended in deionized water, and subsequently the metal precursors were added into the suspension. The water was removed after stirring overnight and the solid was dried at 120 °C for 10 h. We then calcined the solid at 300 °C for 1 h. The catalyst was reduced in 20 ml/min H2 flow at 650 °C for 3 h. NixCoy denotes the Ni of x wt% and the Co of y wt% in the γ-Al2O3-supported catalyst. 2.2 Catalyst characterization We employed powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) to examine the crystalline structure of the catalysts by an X'pert Pro-Philips diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 0.154 nm, 2θ = 5∼80°, step size 0.0167°, step counting time 10 s). The metal loadings of catalysts were examined by employing inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometers (ICP-OES) and the results were listed in Table S1. We performed X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis by an ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer (Al Kα source, 1486.6 eV). The binding energies were corrected based on the reference of C 1 s peak (284.8 eV). CO2-TPD (temperature programmed desorption), NH3-TPD, and H2-TPR (temperature programmed reduction) were performed using a Tp-5080 China Xianquan machine (TCD detector). 0.05 g sample was in these tests. The procedure for H2-TPR is that the sample was first subjected dehydration by ramping the temperature to 110 °C (rate: 5 °C/min) and kept for 1 h. Then, the sample was cooled to 50 °C and subsequently exposed to H2/N2 mixture and heated from 50 to 700 °C (rate: 10 °C/min). For CO2/NH3-TPD, the sample was first reduced in 20 ml/min H2 flow at 650 °C for 3 h; it was then cooled to 50 °C (rate: −10 °C /min) in helium; The sample was exposed to the CO2/NH3 gas for 1 h, and then the gas was changed to helium; Before heating the sample to 600 °C (rate: 10 °C/min) and monitoring the desorption, the signal of the baseline was flat at 50 °C. High resolution transmission electron microscopy was performed to examine microstructure of catalysts using a JEOL JEM-2100EX electron microscopy (200 kV). 2.3 Hydrodeoxygenation of LA We used a 100 mL stainless autoclave to perform hydrodeoxygenation of LA. Typically, 0.90 g LA, 0.30 g catalyst, and 29.10 g 2-propanol were added into the autoclave. The autoclave was purged and pressurized to 5 MPa with pure H2. Then the reaction was performed at a desired temperature and a stirring rate of 500 rpm for 5 h. After reaction, products in the organic phase and gas phase were analyzed using a GC-2014C equipped with HP-INNOWAX column, while the products in the aqueous phase were analyzed using a Waters e2695 high performance liquid chromatography equipped with a Shodex SUAGER SH1011 column (mobile phase: 0.5 mL·min−1 10 mM aqueous sulfuric acid). The products were confirmed by an Agilent 7890A-5975C GCMS–. The LA conversion and yield of products were calculated using the equations: (1) L A c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = ( n ( L A ) i n − − n ( L A ) o u t ) / n ( L A ) i n × 100 % (2) Y i e l d ( % ) = n p r o d u c t / n ( L A ) i n × 100 % where nA denotes the n moles of A. 2.4 Molecular dynamics simulations To analyze the solvent effect on dehydration of 1,4-PeD to 2-MTHF, the NAMD [29] / Visual Molecular Dynamics (VMD) [30] suite and the Chemistry at HARvard Macromolecular Mechanics (CHARMM) force-filed [31] were employed to carry out molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. One 1,4-PeD molecule was solvated using explicit water (TIP3P, containing 3892 atoms in this system), ethanol (containing 4519 atoms), and 2-propanol (containing 4219 atoms). We first optimized the system volume in an NPT ensemble for 1.2 ns after energy minimization (500 steps) using a time-step of 2 fs for all systems. We then launched 400 ns MD simulations at 250 °C in an NVT ensemble with a time-step of 2 fs. The temperature was controlled using the Langevin thermostat and the pressure was maintained using the Nosé-Hoover barostat. We applied the periodic boundary conditions for all simulations. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization XRD analysis: The prepared catalysts were characterized by XRD with patterns shown in Fig. 1 . The support γ-Al2O3 showed the peaks at 2θ = 37°, 39°, 46°, and 67°, which correspond to the crystalline planes of (311), (222), (400), and (440) (JCPDS no. 29–1486) [32]. The intensity of these peaks decreased after metal immobilization on the support, while the remained peaks of support suggested no phase transformation of the support. We also observed that the peaks became smaller and broader, indicative of well dispersed metals or metal oxides and a strong interaction between the support and metal (or metal oxides). For the Ni30, we observed the peaks at 2θ = 44°, 52°, and 75°, which were assigned to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of Ni metal with space group of F m 3 ¯ m (JCPDS no. 04–0850). [33] We also observed the same peaks in the Co30 catalyst, which were also ascribed to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of Co metal ( F m 3 ¯ m , JCPDS no. 15–0806), [34] although the intensity was much lower than Ni30. The gradual addition of Co to the Ni catalyst led to gradually decreased intensity of these peaks in the Ni25Co5, Ni15Co15, and Ni5Co25 catalysts. We also observed an additional small diffraction peak at 2θ = 31° for Ni5Co25 catalyst, which can be assigned to CoO or Co2O3 [35]. No obvious peaks of other metal oxides were observed, probably due to homogenous dispersion of these metal oxides. XPS analysis: The valence states of metals on the surface of the catalysts were examined by XPS characterization. The deconvoluted XPS spectra of Ni 2p and Co 2p were presented in Fig. 2 , while that of other elements (Al and O) was provided in Figure S1 and the surface component fractions were listed in Table S2. The peaks of Ni species can be classified into: (i) satellite peaks at binding energies ∼ 879 eV and ∼ 860 eV; (ii) the peaks of Ni0 2p1/2 at ∼871 eV and Ni0 2p3/2 at ∼ 853 eV; and (ii) the peaks of Ni2+ 2p1/2 at ∼ 875 eV and Ni2+ 2p3/2 at ∼ 856 eV (Fig. 2a). [36–38] It is important to note that the peaks of Ni 2p3/2 in Ni metal, NiO, and Ni(OH)2 are at binding energy ∼ 852.6 eV, ∼ 853.7 eV, to ∼ 855.6 eV, respectively [36,37]. We observed that the Ni30 and Ni15Co15 showed the respective Ni 2p3/2 peak at 852.6 eV and 852.3 eV, indicative of the existence of Ni metal on the surface. In contrast, no Ni metal peaks were observed on the surface of Ni25Co5 and Ni5Co25. The ratio of Ni2+/Ni0 on the surface of Ni30 was 1.53, while that of Ni15Co15 was 0.80 with more observed Ni0 state. It highlights that γ-Al2O3-supported NixCoy with appropriate Ni/Co ratio is helpful in reduction of nickel oxide and in maintaining the reduced states of Ni species. The lower Ni 2p3/2 peak of Ni25Co5 was at a binding energy of 853.9 eV, indicative the existence of NiO, while that of Ni25Co5 was at 855.0 eV, highlighting that the Ni(OH)2 was on the surface of Ni5Co25. The XPS characterization of Co 2p is shown in Fig. 2b. Four predominant peaks were observed and can be classified into two satellite peaks at approximately 802 eV and 785 eV; Co 2p1/2 at ∼ 796 eV; and Co 2p3/2 at ∼ 780 eV. The Co 2p3/2 of Co metal showed a peak at binding energy ∼778 eV, while that of CoO and Co2O3 showed a peak at ∼ 779.5 eV [39,40]. The difference between Co2+ and Co3+ is that Co2+ had a satellite peak at ∼786 eV while no observable peak for Co3+. [39] For the Co30 catalyst, we observed the Co 2p3/2 peak at 778.5 eV, highlighting the existence of Co0. Referenced to Co30, all the catalysts showed higher binding energies larger than 779.4 eV for Co 2p3/2 feature (781.5 eV of Ni5Co25, 779.4 eV of Ni15Co15, and 780.5 eV for Ni25Co5), indicative of majority of cobalt oxides on the surface. It also suggests that nickel oxides may hinder the reduction of cobalt oxides due to competition reduction between two metal oxides. Indeed, the satellite peak around 785 eV was unobserved in Ni25Co5, indicative of the majority of Co3+, which further reinforced the hypothesis of the competition reduction between nickel oxides and cobalt oxides. To summarize, the XPS results highlighted that the interaction and competition between Ni and Co (oxides) modified the surface properties of catalysts and electronic states of metals, which could tune the catalysts to be more reactive. Acidity of catalysts: The acidic sites of catalysts play an important role in dehydration (large amounts) and CC cleavage (low amounts). [41–44] For example, Lewis acidic sites promote the production of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural from saccharides dehydration [42] while Brønsted sites improve alcoholysis of LA and furfuryl alcohol to alkyl levulinates. [44] Combination of hydrogenation metal site and Lewis acidic site facilitated hydrogenation of LA to GVL. [10] For catalytic hydrodeoxygenation of LA to 2-MTHF, cyclodehydration of the intermediate of 1,4-PeD should be promoted while side reaction of CC cleavage of 1,4-PeD to 2-butanol should be minimized. Therefore, it is of importance to test the acidic properties of the catalysts. We measured the acidic properties of the NixCoy catalysts by carrying out temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) experiments (Fig. 3 ). The NH3 desorption feature can be generally categorized into three domains, weak (< 250 °C), medium (250–400 °C), and strong (> 400 °C) acidic sites. [45] For the γ-Al2O3-supported NixCoy, the weak acidic sites were assigned to the weak Lewis acid and Brønsted acid sites, such as Ni(OH)+, [46] (CoOH)+ species; [47] the medium acidic sites were attributed to the interactions of NH3 and protons at the M1-(OH)-M2 sites (M1, M2 = Al, Co, Ni); and the strong acidic sites were assigned to strong Lewis sites M1 O-M2 and strong Brønsted sites. [45] We observed that Co-based catalysts showed four dominant featured peaks in NH3-TPD tests, containing all three different acidic sites. However, the Ni30 only showed three observable peaks with the highest desorption peak at ∼380 °C, probably due to the majority of Ni0 state and few M1 O-M2 sites, which agreed well with the XPS results. The total acidity of Ni30 was 0.176 mmol·g −1, with 0.147 mmol·g −1 medium acidic sites and 0.029 mmol·g −1 weak acidic sites (Table 1 ). With the gradual increase amount of cobalt, the catalysts showed strong acidic sites. The amounts of strong acidic sites for Ni25Co5, Ni15Co15, Ni5Co25, and Co30 were 0.014, 0.127, 0.090, 0.056 mmol·g −1. Although the Ni15Co15 showed highest amount of strong acidic sites, cobalt showed a higher ability to increase the amount of strong acidity than nickel, highlighting that the addition of cobalt could facilitate the dehydration of 1,4-PeD to 2-MTHF than Ni monometallic catalyst. Nevertheless, this phenomenon could be resulted from the partially unreduced metal oxides which led to the formation of M1 O-M2 sites, which was consistent with the XRD and XPS results. We also observed that the NiCo bimetallic catalysts showed higher amounts of weak acidity and medium acidity than monometallic catalysts (Table 1). It is highly possible due to increased amount of metal oxides and the formation of Ni-O-Co and Ni-(OH)-Co species. Basicity of catalysts: We further examined the basicity of catalysts by performing CO2-TPD experiments. As shown in Figure S2, three predominant peaks of CO2 desorption were observed: ∼ 160 °C, ∼ 227 °C, and ∼ 391 °C. The first desorption peak (∼ 160 °C) was the most intensive peak locating at the same position for all the tested catalysts. However, the intensity for the second peak (∼ 227 °C) was different. The Ni5Co25 catalyst showed the most intensive peak among all tested catalysts. It highlighted different surface structure and property in γ-Al2O3-supported NixCoy catalysts, which agreed well with the other characterization results. The third desorption peaks were broad and tiny in all catalysts, although their positions varied. The total amounts of basicity were approximately 0.6∼0.7 mmol·g −1 with no big difference observed. H2-TPR analysis: We performed H2 temperature programmed reduction (TPR) experiments to probe the reducible properties of the catalysts (Figure S3). As shown in Figure S3, two major peaks were observed in Ni30 at ∼189 and 347 °C, which were attributed to the surface and bulk Ni2+, respectively. There were three predominant peaks in Co-based catalysts, ∼ 175 °C, ∼ 341 °C, ∼ 402 °C. It highlighted that the addition of cobalt increased the amount of metal oxides, which was consistent with the results of XRD, XPS, and NH3-TPD experiments. The peak at ∼ 175 °C was assigned to the reduction of cobalt oxides, which was shifted from 150 °C (Co30) to 175 °C with the addition of nickel into cobalt catalysts. These results highlight that the introducing of Ni decreases the reduction of Co oxides while the introducing of Co facilitates the reduction of Ni oxides. It reinforced the hypothesis of the competition effect of two metal oxides (XPS test). The other peaks were assigned to the reduction of both two metal oxides, including NiO, CoO, and Co2O3 [48,49]. TEM-Mapping analysis: To evaluate the morphology of the catalyst, TEM and elemental mapping analysis have been performed for Ni15Co15 and Ni5Co25 (Figure S4). The TEM images of Ni15Co15 in Figure S4 (a-e), in which nanoparticles were relatively small, showed uniformly distributed particles on the γ-Al2O3. The lattice fringes of Ni were observed in the HRTEM image presented in the Figure S4 (e). The lattice fridge spacing of 0.238 nm was indexed to the (111) plane of the Ni metal, in line with the result of XRD. While no obvious particles were observed in the HRTEM image of Ni5Co25, which indicated that the Co component was amorphous and the high distribution of Ni on the catalyst surface. As displayed in Figure S4 (k-o), the elemental mapping of Ni5Co25 showed that the Ni and Co are well dispersed on the γ-Al2O3. 3.2 Catalytic performance Hydrodeoxygenation of LA: The characterizations of the prepared catalysts showed different components on the surface and properties, which can affect the reaction. Therefore, we carried out hydrodeoxygenation of LA catalyzed by γ-Al2O3-supported NixCoy catalysts with the results presented in Table 2 . The reaction conditions were 5 MPa H2, 250 °C, and 5 h reaction time in a 2-propanol medium. The main products were 2-MTHF, 2-butanol, 2-pentanol, 1,4-PeD, and GVL. As expected, the catalysts with different Ni/Co ratio showed distinct behavior, although all catalysts showed activity of 100% LA conversion (Table 2, entries 1–7). The Ni30 showed the highest activity of producing monoalcohol with the yield of 54.0% 2-butanol and 15.7% 2-pentanol, indicative of appreciable reactivity of hydrogenation and CC cleavage of nickel species. With the gradually increased component of cobalt species in catalyst, the yield of 2-MTHF was increased to 42.1% over Ni25Co5, 40.8% over Ni20Co10, 43.4% over Ni15Co15, 62.1% over Ni10Co20, and 70.6% over Ni5Co15. Meanwhile, the yield of monoalcohol was decreased and reached 16.7% of 2-butanol and 8.0% of 2-pentanol over the Ni5Co15 catalyst. This observation suggested a decreased activity of CC cleavage and an increased activity of dehydration of cobalt-rich NiCo bimetallic catalyst. It is possible due to the increased component of metal oxides and remained component of metal states (for hydrogenation activity) as revealed by XPS analysis and decreased Ni metal sites with introducing of Co species, which provided more acidic sites as disclosed by NH3-TPD analysis and inhibited activity of over-hydrodeoxygenation (CC and CO cleavage reactions to produce byproducts 2-butanol and 2-pentanol) by nickel metal. The Co30 catalyst also showed high reactivity of producing 2-MTHF from LA hydrodeoxygenation due to its partially reduced cobalt which provided hydrogenation activity and remained cobalt metal oxides which provided acidic sites. Nonetheless, the Ni5Co25 catalyst presented the highest reactivity and a highest yield of 2-MTHF, highlighting that the interaction of Ni and Co metal (oxides) improved the reactivity. We also looked into the effect of reduction temperature of the Ni5Co25 catalysts on hydrodeoxygenation of LA (Table 1, entries 8–12). Besides the reduction temperature of 650 °C, other five temperatures were tested. Although the yield of 2-MTHF varied over the five tested Ni5Co25 catalysts, the yields of 2-MTHF were lower than 60%. It suggested that the reduction temperature of 650 °C rendered the highest reactivity of Ni5Co25 catalysts. Optimization of reaction conditions: Besides the properties of catalyst, the reaction conditions are also important effects on the hydrodeoxygenation of LA to produce 2-MTHF. Therefore, we subsequently varied the reaction conditions including reaction temperature, H2 pressure, reaction time and catalyst dosage of Ni5Co25 to optimize the LA conversion and the yield of 2-MTHF (Fig. 4 ). The reaction temperature was a significant factor affecting the LA conversion and product distribution (Fig. 4a). The LA conversion was 90.2% at 130 °C and reached 100% at temperature higher than 190 °C. The main liquid product was GVL at the reaction temperature lower than 220 °C, although other products such as GVL, 1,4-PeD, 2-butanol, and 2-pentanol were also observed. Specifically, the selectivity of GVL was 100% at 130, 150, and 170 °C. The yield of GVL was reached the highest (94.8%) at 190 °C and was gradually decreased with the increased temperature, while the yield of 2-MTHF was increased from 0.3% at 190 °C to 73.4% at 240 °C. Meanwhile, the yield of 2-butanol was increased from 0.1% at 190 °C to 22.0% at 230 °C. This observation suggested the competition between the reactivities of producing 2-MTHF and 2-butanol from LA hydrodeoxygenation, highlighting the sensitivity of surface properties of catalyst to improve dehydration activity and inhibit the CC cleavage activity. When the reaction temperature was further increased to 250 °C, the yield of 2-MTHF was slightly decreased to 70.6%, indicating that higher temperature could lead to side reactions. H2 is one of the sources providing the reductant for LA hydrodeoxygenation. The effect of H2 pressure was carried out under the conditions of 240 °C and 5 h with the result shown in Fig. 4b. When the pressure was 1 MPa, the yield of 2-MTHF was 32.8%, although the main product was GVL (54.2%). We observed gradual increase of the yield of 2-MTHF with the increasing pressure of H2 from 1 MPa to 5 MPa and the yield of 2-MTHF was reached 73.4% at 5 MPa. Further increase of pressure to 6 MPa did not promote the yield of 2-MTHF, indicative of a saturated state of M-H (M = Ni and Co) species on the surface at 5 MPa. We also noticed the gradual increase of the yield of 2-butanol, which further highlighted the competition of reactivities between producing 2-MTHF and monoalcohol. The evolution of LA hydrodeoxygenation under conditions of 240 °C and 5 MPa H2 was monitored (Fig. 4c). Initially (1 h), a low yield of 2-MTHF (12.4%) was observed while GVL was the main product (76.3%), indicative of insufficient reaction time to produce 2-MTHF. As the reaction time increased to 5 h, the yield of 2-MTHF was 73.4% and an increased yield of 2-butanol was also observed. An extended reaction time (6 h) led to a slightly decreased yield of 2-MTHF (72.7%), while the yield of 2-butanol was increased to 16.9%. The effect of Ni5Co25 dosage on LA hydrodeoxygenation is presented in Fig. 4d. When the catalyst dosage was 0.10 g, the LA conversion was 75.3% and the yield of 2-MTHF was 47.7%. A 15.8% yield of 2-butanol was also observed. The yields of 2-MTHF were approximately 73% with 100% conversion when the catalyst dosage increased to 0.30 g or higher, indicative of a sufficient dosage of 0.30 g Ni5Co25. Reuse potential of Ni5Co25 Catalyst: In order to investigate the reuse potential of the Ni5Co25 catalyst, four consecutive cycles of LA hydrodeoxygenation were performed to maintain the incomplete conversion of LA under the conditions of 5 MPa H2, 240 °C and 4 h (Fig. 5 ). After four consecutive runs, the conversion of LA and yield of 2-MTHF were dropped slightly. A comparative yield of 2-MTHF (decreased from 66.1% to 62.9%) were observed for these four runs with the conversion of LA decreased from 92.4% to 87.3% gradually. It indicated the Ni5Co25 catalyst might have a good stability and reusability. 3.3 Solvent effect To understand the solvent role in affecting LA hydrodeoxygenation, we employed three solvents water, ethanol, and 2-propanol to perform LA hydrodeoxygenation under the conditions of 3 MPa H2, 250 °C, and 2 h over the Ni15Co15 catalyst (Table 3 ). Full conversion of LA was observed in all tests, while the product distributions were different. A highest yield of GVL (80.6%) and a lowest yield of 2-MTHF (13.4%) were detected in the aqueous medium. In the primary alcohol ethanol solvent, the yield of 2-MTHF was slightly increased to 16.4%. With the presence of the secondary alcohol 2-propanol, the yield of 2-MTHF was increased to 32.7%, which clearly suggested that 2-propanol assisted selective production of 2-MTHF from LA hydrodeoxygenation. The possible reasons include: (i) 2-propanol provided the hydride through hydrogen transfer reaction as demonstrated in previous studies, [17] and (ii) a higher H2 dissolvability due to a lower polarity [14]. Other than these two merits of 2-propanol solvent, we hypothesized that the structure of intermediate 1,4-PeD was an important factor affecting the reaction. The rationale behind this hypothesis includes: (i) the dehydration of 1,4-PeD to form 2-MTHF requires a close position between two hydroxyl groups; and (ii) the interaction of 1,4-PeD with solvent can prevent the two hydroxyl groups from forming the close position. Therefore, we performed MD simulations to verify our hypothesis. We measured the distance between oxygen from the two hydroxyl groups of 1,4-PeD and the probability distribution of the distance is shown in Fig. 6 . We observed that there were two major states for the distance corresponding to 2.85 Å (short-distance) and 5.30 Å (long-distance) in all three systems. The short-distance showed a close position between two hydroxyl groups which could assist the dehydration of 1,4-PeD to form 2-MTHF, while a higher energy barrier was required to overcome to facilitate the dehydration reaction for the long-distance position. A high probability of long-distance position was observed in all three systems. However, the probability of long-distance position was highest in aqueous medium compared with that in organic solvents. On the contrary, a higher probability of short-distance was observed in the 2-propanol and ethanol mediums compared with aqueous systems. It is probably because water molecule has a smaller volume and can stabilize the long-distance position by forming hydrogen-bond between many water molecules with 1,4-PeD, compared with larger volume molecules ethanol and 2-propanol. Although 1,4-PeD in ethanol medium shows similar probability in short-distance position, it does not have high H2 dissolvability and cannot act as a reductant in the reaction. Nonetheless, this result verified our hypothesis and highlighted the importance and sensitivity of reactant's structure to facilitate the reaction. 4 Conclusion In this study, we reported the production of 2-MTHF from LA over bimetallic NiCo catalyst. The effects of Ni/Co ratio and solvent on the reaction were systematically studied. It presented that the catalytic activity depends on the Ni/Co ratio. The investigations of XRD and XPS revealed the existence of metal and metal oxides in NixCoy catalyst, both of which were important factors that metal was responsible for activation of H2 to promote the hydrogenation reaction and metal oxides provided the acidic sites to facilitate the dehydration reaction. Different ratios of Ni/Co resulted in distinct electronic states of metals on surface and acidic properties, which were attributed to the distinct reactivity and product distributions. We employed MD simulations to understand the solvent effect and the result revealed a higher probability of a short-distance position in 2-propanol medium, which could facilitate the formation of 2-MTHF through dehydration of 1,4-PeD. Insights into the effects of Ni/Co ratio and solvent promotion on the one-pot hydrodeoxygenation of LA to 2-MTHF can beneficial for the design of catalytic system in biomass or biomass-derived compounds valorization. coredata.dc:description: The production of furanic biofuel 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF) has been studied by hydrodeoxygenation of biomass-derived levulinic acid (LA) over bimetallic NiCo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The contents of Ni and Co in NiCo/γ-Al2O3 were investigated. The Ni5Co25/γ-Al2O3 catalyst gave high activity in hydrodeoxygenation of LA with a 73.4% yield of 2-MTHF under optimal conditions. The crystal phase, valence states, acidity and basicity of catalysts were measured by multiple characterizations to understand the relationships among 2-MTHF yields and catalyst properties. XPS characterization revealed that the number of metal oxides increased on bimetallic catalysts while the reduced metals occupied on monometallic catalysts. The bimetallic catalysts also presented increased acidity than that of monometallic catalysts. These distinct properties were also observed among bimetallic catalysts with different contents of Ni and Co, which were responsible for different performances. Besides, the solvent effect on the structure of 1,4-pentanediol, which was further converted to 2-methyltetrahydrofuran, was disclosed by molecular dynamics simulations.
coredata.dc:title: One-pot conversion of biomass-derived levulinic acid to furanic biofuel 2-methyltetrahydrofuran over bimetallic NiCo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts
